Comment: In queen pawn openings I have noticed that a great many players will move the queen bishop early, and this is a mistake, as I have mentioned many times in my chess lessons, because White will at the very least gain a tempo when he plays Qb3 later attacking the b7 pawn.
Better would have been 5. Nbd2 Nb6 6. e4
Better would have been 5. Nbd2 Nb6 6. e4
Strengthens the white center.
Now if 7... Qc7 8. e4 Bxe4 9. Ng5 Bg6 10. Bf4 Qxf4 11. Qxb7 e6 12. Bb5+ Kd8 13. Qxa8 Bd6 14. Nh3 Qf5 15. Qxa7 cxd4 16. Qb6+ Ke7 (16... Bc7 17. Qxd4+) 17. Qb7+ Kf6 18. cxd4

White can win with 8. Ng5 Bg6  (Sidelining the bishop gives white this big advantage.) 9. e4 h6 10. Qxb7 Nd7 11. Bb5 Rc8 (11... Rb8 12. Bxd7+) 12. Nf3 Qc7 13. Qxc7 Rxc7 14. Bf4 Rb7 15. Ba4 Kd8 (15... Bxe4 16. dxc5 [with a winning game.]) 16. Rd1 c4 17. Ne5 Nb6 (17... Nb8 18. Ke2 Kc8 (18... Bxe4 19. Nxf7+) 19. f3 e6 20. Rb1 Rxb1 (20... Bd6 21. Nxg6) 21. Rxb1 Na6 22. Bd7+ Kd8 23. Rb7 Nc7 24. Nxg6) 18. Bc6

This move is simply wrong.  White tries too hard to press the advantage, thinking that after cxd4 he could play a combination of Ba6 and Bf4, forgetting that Bf4 black can meet with e5. 

Instead 13. e3 is simple and winning.

White's best chance is 14. cxd4 Nxd4 15. Rb1 Bc5 16. Ba6  equal.
Now 15. a4 dxc3 16. Bb5 Rc8  is close to equal.
The problem with White's failed plan is that this pawn on c3 is winning for black.
